70.title: "The Whisper Mystery"
70.author: by Daniel Torres
70.appears_in: p. 44-51 in Heavy Metal, v. 9, no. 4 (July 1985).
notes: Synopsis (from p. 4): "While working on the new Sam Norton episode for SF magazine, Armando Mistral is visited by his old friend Chico Panama, a womanizer and a cheat. Unable to get rid of Panama, Mistral hotfoots it over to Montebahia for a bit of r&r, where he runs into Cuper and a bunch of thugs fighting it out."
Plates numbered 18-25.
"To be continued."

71.title: "The Whisper Mystery"
71.author: by Daniel Torres
71.appears_in: p. 41-48 in Heavy Metal, v. 9, no. 5 (Aug. 1985).
notes: "Catch Up (from p. 39): While working on the new Sam Norton episode for SF magazine, Armando Mistral is visited by his old friend Chico Panama, a womanizer and a cheat. Unable to get rid of Panama, Mistral hotfoots it over to Montebahia for a bit of r&r, where he runs into Archie Cooper, a Chandleresque detective, and a bunch of thugs fighting it out. Cooper is murderered by a bunch of human-size lizards, and Chop Jones (the man behind this whole drug-related mess in the first place) pays Mistral a visit."

72.title: "The Whisper Mystery"
72.author: by Daniel Torres

notes: Final installment.
Plates numbered 34-36.

130.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Brawny grabs Lard's nose and lectures him about the rules of TWIRP Season, and then Flossie Fidge gives them a wolf whistle.

131.author: [No author]

132.heading: Whistles.
132.title: "Maybe You've Got a Whistle Only Dogs Can Hear"
132.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: A younger man hanging by the water cooler with Brutus is whistling at female co-workers, and they ignore him.

133.heading: Whistles.
133.title: "Near Calamity"
133.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Pat Owen comes out of the drugstore and we hear a wolf whistle; it's the peanut vendor, but Lard almost gets blamed and drummed out of the corps: It's still Woman-Hating Week.

134.heading: Whistles.
134.title: "She Got One of those Whistles only a Dog Can Hear"
134.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Maude lets Cliff out of the house only if he takes Spot along; Spot's leash is hooked to a leg iron on Cliff.

139.heading: Whistles.
139.title: "Wanted, an Automobile"
139.author: King.
notes: Summary: Doc is dissatisfied with his car, because a truck backed into it, he missed a traffic whistle, he ran out of gas, he forgot to connect one of the spark plugs, etc.

140.heading: Whistlestop Tours.

142.title: The Whistlin' Kid

notes: "The Whistlin' Kid was famous on our Western plains as a hard-riding, fast-shooting cowboy."

143.heading: Whistling.
143.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
143.author: [No author]

144.heading: Whistling.
144.title: "Books, Not Babes"
144.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: The Mr. Wilson informs Freck and Lard that they've whistled at Miss Darcy, the new social science teacher. He's glad they approve of the faculty, but gives them a warning.

145.heading: Whistling.
145.title: "Death Whistles a Silent Song" 2 p. in DC Special Series, no. 4
145.author: [No author]

146.heading: Whistling.
146.title: "Hiring a New Maid"
146.author: by Stan Lee
146.appears_in: 5 p. in Millie the Model Comics, no. 20 (Oct. 1949).
notes: Summary: Veronica's whistle annoys Hedy, but the applicants to replace her are even more annoying.
Begins: Ah, this is the way I like to spend a Sunday afternoon!

147.heading: Whistling.
147.title: "Is That Passing?"
147.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Freckles gets a report card from Miss Darcy, grading his diplomacy, whistling, and effort. His last name is McGoosey.

148.heading: Whistling.
148.title: "Modern Dentistry Can Perform Only So Many Miracles"
148.author: Pat Brady.
notes: Summary: Pasquale's mouth still can't do bubblegum or whistling.

149.heading: Whistling.
149.title: "Not That Way"
149.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Miss Darcy says whistling at women might be the wrong idea, and that perhaps they should let women do some of the pursuing.

150.heading: Whistling.
150.title: "Le Retour de Joe La-Gâchette" p. 6-22 in Sous le Ciel de l'Ouest
150.author: textes et dessins de Morris, in Lucky Luke : Spécial 2 (Marcinelle-Charleroi, Belgique : Dupuis, 1980).
notes: Summary: Near the town of Nugget Gulch, Lucky Luke meets a bearded man who calls himself John the Philanthropist. John says he's a peaceful man, and that the notches on his revolver aren't his, because he just found it and doesn't really use it well. When a cobra comes from behind a rock and John draws and kills it in one swift motion, Lucky Luke has to wonder about his story. In Nugget Gulch a horse race is planned for the next day. Since John and Lucky Luke are both low on money, they both decide to enter. John has seen Jolly Jumper run, and knows he can't beat such a horse, but he enters the race anywhow. Betting is heavy on the race, and a series of colorful charcters are entered, including a Mexican rider named "Pedro Nice Chink" riding a mule named "Flower of the Orient," and a overweight man called "Texas Slim." When Lucky Luke goes to get Jolly Jumper for the race, he finds the horse missing. The race starts without Lucky Luke. John the Philanthropist's horse is black, until a rain shower washes the stain off and the stolen Jolly Jumper is revealed. Lucky Luke whistles, and Jolly Jumper dumps John into a rain barrel. Lucky Luke and Jolly Jumper are win the race together, inspired by an electric shock after a collision with a telegraph pole. John steals all the money and runs for it on his own horse. Lucky Luke telegraphs ahead to Rattlesnake Valley, and has "poison" signs put on all the water holes in the desert. John is soon crazy with thirst and easily caught. Lucky Luke has him shaved and he turns out to be the wanted outlaw Joe La-Gâchette.

151.heading: Whistling.
151.title: "That Was Just a Coincidence!"
151.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: Broom-Hilda thinks she's being whistled at, but actually the man is calling his dog.

152.heading: Whistling.
152.title: "Wasting No Time"
152.author: by Blosser.
notes: Summary: Lard and Freckles whistle at the new girl in the schoolyard, and she's talking to Mr. Wilson the principal.

153.heading: "The Whistling Death" / Johnny Bell. 5 p. in Wings Comics, no.
153.author: [No author]
notes: Cover blurb: "Red terror rode on robot rockets."
Korean War story.

154.heading: "The Whistling Death."
154.title: "The Red Skull"
154.author: Joe Simon, Jack Kirby, script ; Jack Kirby, pencils ; Joe Simon, inks
154.appears_in: 13 p. in Captain America Comics, no. 7 (Oct. 1941) ; reprinted in Fantasy Masterpieces, no. 6 (Dec. 1966)
notes: Villain The Red Skull (Johann Schmidt) is introduced.
The title in quotes in the splash-page caption is "An Ear for Music" ; the contents page title is "The Case of the Red Skull and the Whistling Death."
Data from Lou Mougin and Tony R. Rose via Grand Comics Database Project.

155.title: "Whistling Monkey Cowboy Band Land"
155.author: Kirkman & Scott.
notes: Summary: Dad greets proposed day trip with nothing that could be said in mixed company.
Key word: Amusement parks.

156.title: Whirlwind Comics
notes:
Anthology style comic book. Features include
  • Bruce Barlow (issues 1-3)
  • Cyclone (issues 1-3)
  • Dick Blaze (issues 1-3)
  • Doodad the Detective (issues 1-2)
  • Inspector Blake (issues 1-3)
  • Lt. Jim Landis (issues 1-2)
  • Rex Royce of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (issues 1-3)
  • Scoop Hanlon (issues 2-3)
  • Smash Dawson (issues 1-3)
  • Snapper Smith (issue 3)
  • Wings Bordon (issues 1, 3)
This list originates from the one in Howard Keltner's Index to Golden Age Comic Books (Detroit, Mich. : J. Bails, 1976).
